sect1.title: Description of the Disorders
sect1.para: The group group of Somatic Symptom and Related Disorders (SSRD) is a heterogeneous group of different different mental disorders. This diagnostic group has undergone significant modifications over the past decade. The Somatoform Disorders in the fourth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV) (American Psychiatric Association, 2000 ) were replaced by the renamed and reconceptualized group of SSRD in the fifth revision of the DSM (DSM-5) (American Psychiatric Association, 2013 ). Somatic Symptom Disorder (SSD) replaced the previous diagnostic entities of Somatization Disorder, Undifferentiated Somatoform Disorders, and Pain Disorder in the DSM-IV. Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder (FNSD) represents the equivalent to the former Conversion Disorder, as does Illness Anxiety Disorder (IAD) to the former Hypochondriasis. Psychological Factors Affecting Other Medical Conditions (PFAOMC) and Factitious Disorder (FD) were not included in the former group of Somatoform Disorders in the DSM-IV but in other chapters. By introducing the SSRD, the requirement requirement of distinguishing between medically unexplained and explained physical symptoms was abolished and the focus was shifted to symptom-related psychological distress. In this sense, the DSM-5 makes an impactful step in counteracting body-mind dualism by including psychological features as classification criteria and conceptualizing somatic symptoms in terms of a biopsychosocial model. In the following, the features of each SSRD are described in detail. Note these disorders were not revised in the text revision of the DSM-5, the DSM-5-TR (American Psychiatric Association, 2022 ).

Individuals with common functional somatic syndromes (FSS) functional somatic syndromes (FSS) , defined as “well-recognized clusters of bodily symptoms that are common in medical practice and cause considerable disability” (Henningsen et al., 2018 ; p. 12), often present with psychological features that meet the criteria of an SSD. The three most common and best investigated FSS FSS are Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) (Lacy et al., 2016 ), Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS) or Systemic Exertion Intolerance Disease (SEID) (Committee on the Diagnostic Criteria for Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome, 2015 ), and Fibromyalgia (FMS) (World Health Organization, 2018 ).

sect2.title: Illness Anxiety Disorder (IAD)
sect2.para: The central feature of IAD IAD is intense fear about the possibility of having or developing a serious illness. The DSM-5-TR criteria of IAD (American Psychiatric Association, 2022 ) emphasize the absenceof somatic symptoms. The focus is on worrying and typical illness behaviors (e. g., frequent visits to physicians to seek reassurance about a feared illness). Individuals who predominantly experience somatic symptoms and who present with anxieties about their symptoms and behaviors that aim at symptom relief are classified with SSD. A substantial subgroup of individuals with IAD avoids physicians due to intense anxiety about receiving a confirmation confirmation of a diagnosis they fear (Scarella et al., 2019 ).

sect2.title: Factitious Disorder (FD)
sect2.para: A diagnosis of FD FD is made when individuals intentionally feign or produce either somatic or psychological symptoms, although there is no obvious external incentive (American Psychiatric Association, 2022 ). The term FD is historically related to the “ Munchausen’s Syndrome ” which is a more severe form of chronic fabrication of symptoms (American Psychiatric Association, 2022 ; Hausteiner-Wiehle & Hungerer, 2020 ). The DSM-5-TR differentiates between FD Imposed on Self and FD Imposed on Another (or “by Proxy”). FD Imposed on Another is an ethically and legally complex disorder, in which the perpetrator’s behavior behavior might represent criminal behavior. A more modern form of FD is indicated as “by internet” or “by Google,” when stories of illness are disseminated on the internet. Methods that individuals who are diagnosed with FD apply to feign or produce symptoms vary. Examples are false or exaggerated reports of symptoms, exacerbating existing disease (e. g., interfering with wound healing), psychiatric symptoms through use of psychoactive substances substances , manipulating laboratory test, or induced bleeding.
